questions.question: To maintain a legal Scope of Practice (SOP), which of the following actions is a Trauma Recovery Specialist strictly prohibited from performing?
options: Providing psychoeducation on the nervous system
Diagnosing Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) or other DSM-5 conditions
Teaching grounding and stabilization techniques
Facilitating peer-support recovery groups
questions.explanation: Trauma Recovery Specialists focus on recovery and coaching; clinical diagnosis is reserved for licensed mental health professionals (LCSW, LPC, Psychologists, etc.).

questions.question: In ethical branding, why is the use of 'trauma porn' (graphic imagery or descriptions of traumatic events) discouraged in marketing materials?
options: It is too expensive to produce high-quality graphic content
It violates copyright laws regarding survivor stories
It can cause vicarious trauma or triggers in potential clients before they have established safety
It makes the brand look unprofessional and cluttered
questions.explanation: Trauma-informed marketing prioritizes the safety of the audience. Graphic content can dysregulate potential clients, contradicting the 'safety-first' principle of trauma recovery.

questions.question: Which pricing strategy involves offering a set number of sessions at a lower per-unit cost to encourage commitment to the recovery process?
options: Value-based hourly billing
Retainer-based premium pricing
Package-based pricing
Pro-bono only model
questions.explanation: Package-based pricing provides financial predictability for the practitioner and encourages the client to commit to the long-term nature of trauma recovery.

questions.question: When designing a trauma-informed virtual environment, which 'background' choice is considered most supportive for a client's nervous system?
options: A busy bookshelf with many titles to demonstrate expertise
A bright, high-contrast digital filter with moving elements
A neutral, uncluttered, and softly lit physical space
A window directly behind the practitioner showing street traffic
questions.explanation: Visual clutter and high contrast can be overstimulating. A neutral, calm, and stable background helps the client maintain focus and stay within their window of tolerance.

questions.question: What is the primary benefit of building a 'Strategic Referral Network' as discussed in Lesson 5?
options: To receive kickbacks and finders' fees for every client referred
To ensure clients have access to higher levels of care (e.g., psychiatry) when their needs exceed your scope
To eliminate the need for any marketing or branding efforts
To create a monopoly on trauma services in your local area
questions.explanation: Referral networks are essential for safety, allowing practitioners to bridge the gap when a client requires clinical intervention or specialized services outside their scope.

questions.question: During the 'Onboarding Journey,' what is the purpose of a 'Stabilization Screening'?
options: To determine the client's credit score for billing purposes
To assess if the client is currently in acute crisis or lacks basic emotional regulation skills
To gather a detailed, chronological history of every trauma the client has faced
To convince the client to sign up for the most expensive package
questions.explanation: Stabilization screenings ensure that the practitioner is a safe fit for the client and that the client is stable enough to engage in recovery work without being retraumatized.

questions.question: When expanding into digital products (e.g., an automated trauma recovery course), what is a unique ethical challenge for the specialist?
options: Digital products are generally less profitable than 1-on-1 sessions
The lack of real-time support means the content must be exceptionally 'safe' and low-trigger
It is illegal to sell digital recovery products in most jurisdictions
Digital products require a medical license to sell
questions.explanation: Self-paced products lack the 'co-regulation' of a live session, meaning practitioners must be extremely careful to avoid triggering content that a client cannot navigate alone.

questions.question: According to Lesson 8, how does 'Vicarious Trauma' (VT) differ from 'Burnout'?
options: Burnout is only physical, while VT is only emotional
VT specifically involves a shift in the practitionerâ€™s worldview and cognitive schemas due to exposure to client trauma
Burnout only happens to new practitioners, while VT only happens to veterans
There is no difference; the terms are interchangeable in trauma work
questions.explanation: While burnout is related to workload and stress, Vicarious Trauma specifically alters how the practitioner perceives the world (e.g., loss of a sense of safety or trust).

questions.question: A trauma-informed 'Informed Consent' document must explicitly state which of the following to empower the client?
options: The practitioner's home address and personal phone number
The client's right to pause or stop a session at any time for any reason
A guarantee that the client will be fully healed within 10 sessions
A waiver preventing the client from ever seeking clinical therapy
questions.explanation: Empowerment and choice are core pillars of trauma-informed care. Explicitly stating the right to stop ensures the client feels in control of the process.

questions.question: What is considered the 'Gold Standard' for maintaining professional longevity and managing the emotional toll of trauma recovery work?
options: Working 60+ hours a week to gain maximum experience
Avoiding all personal connection with clients
Engaging in regular clinical supervision or peer consultation
Only working with clients who have 'minor' trauma
questions.explanation: Supervision and consultation provide a space for practitioners to process the emotional weight of their work, preventing isolation and vicarious traumatization.
